definition: The codeline or branch that acts as the current state of the product. Usually called `main` or `master`. See {% cite 'fowler-branch-patterns' %} and {% cite 'fowler-ci' %}.
A sequence of versions of a codebase, often in the form of commits to a version control system. See {% cite 'fowler-branch-patterns' %}.
In Git: A movable pointer to a commit. Can also be synonymous with codeline.
A codebase or branch is healthy if it builds successfully with few, if any, bugs. See {% cite 'fowler-branch-patterns' %}.
When used as a UML keyword: A node representing a *physical* computational resource on which artifacts may be deployed. See {% cite 'uml-spec' %}, §19.5.7.
When used as a UML keyword: A node offering an execution environment for specific types of components deployed on it as executable artifacts. See {% cite 'uml-spec' %}, §19.5.8.
When used as a UML keyword: A physical piece of information that is used or produced in software development, or by deployment and operation of a system. See {% cite 'uml-spec' %}, §19.5.1.
In the context of UML: A computational resource upon which artifacts may be deployed. See {% cite 'uml-spec' %}, §19.4.

In the context of UML: A textual annotation that serves to distinguish a particular UML concept from others sharing the same general graphical form. Keywords are always enclosed in guillemets (i.e., «keyword»). Not to be confused with UML stereotypes. See {% cite 'uml-spec' %}, annex C.

In the context of UML: Defines an extension of a UML concept as part of a UML profile. When applied to UML elements, stereotypes are enclosed in guillemets (i.e., «stereotype»). Not to be confused with UML keywords. See {% cite 'uml-spec' %}, §12.3.3.4.

In the context of UML: Extends UML with a collection of stereotypes. The standard profile specifies a set of predefined standard stereotypes. See {% cite 'uml-spec' %}, §12.3 for a description of profiles in general, and §22 for the standard profile.
A single, logical location in an application where modules are composed together. See {% cite 'van-deursen-seemann-di' %}, §4.1.
